description: From Middle English goere, equivalent to go +‎ -er. Compare German Geher (“goer, walker”).

entries.meaning: One who, or that which, goes.
examples: Lord John has been all day in his inner library. His antechamber has been filled with comers and goers, some talking in knots, some writing notes at tables.

entries.meaning: (informal) Anything, especially a machine such as a motor car, that performs well, or operates successfully.
examples: I bought her secondhand, but she's a good little goer.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang) A person, often a woman, who enjoys sexual activity.
examples: Norman: Is your wife a...goer...eh? Know what I mean? Know what I mean? Nudge nudge.
[…]  a double Mantle castA’ thwart his Shoulders, his faire goers g[r]ac’stWith fitted shooes; and in his hand, a Dart

entries.meaning: (dated) A horse, considered in reference to its gait.
